name: 1-methylpyrrole-2-carboxylic acid
Reason: 1-methylpyrrole-2-carboxylic acid has a melting point that can be predicted by considering its structural components. The basic unit for comparison is pyrrole, which has a melting point of 106°C (according to the CRC Handbook of Chemistry and Physics, 49th Edition, 1968-1969). The methyl group introduces a rigid structure, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point. The carboxylic acid group introduces a hydroxyl group, which can participate in hydrogen bonding and increase the melting point. The presence of two additional phenyl rings linked in a linear fashion can be estimated to add approximately 100°C to the melting point due to increased pi-pi interactions, rigidity, and molecular weight.
